children.subject: That's all the excuse I need to get rid of it. Thank you!
Just a note, you should probably replace 172 regardless since it won't be offered anytime soon unless a professor steps in to teach it.

history.content:
You should talk to faculty to get advice. In general, the ML core is 126, 127, and then 189. The core mathy courses for the department are 170 (algorithms), 126 (probability), and 127 (optimization). The core software course is 162. The theory courses of 172 and 174 are both non-core and not as well supported as the core courses. 

In terms of ordering, the standard advice is simple:

 1) Finish the six lower-divs

 2) Take cores in what you think you might like based on lower-divs (e.g. take 126, 127, and 170 if you like mathy theory type stuff)

 3) Go beyond core in the area that you think you like if you still like it, and take along with cores in other areas for broad upper-div strength. (e.g. Take 162 alongside say 189, once you have completed 126 and 127)

 4) If there is an amazing instructor that you really want to take a course with, take advantage of the opportunities when they present themselves, provided that you are ready for the course.
I would not recommend taking 162 alongside 189. Both courses are known to be very difficult.

I'm putting together my schedule for the next five semesters (planning to double major in Applied Math and CS) but I'm seeing a lot of recommendations on Piazza to take 160, 162, etc. My schedule has a lot of theory based cs courses (CS17x), computer graphics, and 188 and 189 (I think these classify as ML). Should I replace my theory classes like 172 and 174 with software engineering courses in the 160s just to be safe? And if I could only pick two, which would you recommend?

I'd like to give a better description of what I'm interested in as a whole, that way it'd be easier to get some insight, but I like all of these topics. I just want to make sure I take what's necessary and THEN focus on fun stuff.
history.subject: Should I take a CS16x course?
